bibl.title: Harry Gong vs. United States. Criminal.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States District Court, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: "Exhibit A"
Record of testimony given by Yut Yow, Chinese prostitute, at Police Station, Portland, Oregon, November 4, 1913, in re legality of her residence in the United States and other matters.
Examination conducted by Inspector in Charge J. H. Barbour.
Herman Lowe, Chinese Interpreter.
Wilfred F. Smith, Stenographer.
Police Officers Harms and Wise, present.
YUT YOW, duly sworn, testified as follows:
Q What is your name ? A Yut x Yow.
Q Any other name or names? A Also known as Ah Sing.

Q You will now be requested to make a statement in regard to the legality of your residence in the United States and other matters. It is your privilege to refuse to make any such statement, and you are informed that any statement you make may be used against you in subsequent proceedings. A All right.
Q How old are you? A Forty-five.
Q Where were you born? A San Francisco.
Q What year? A I don't remember now.
Q Have you ever been in China? A No.
Q Didn't you go to China when you were young? A No.
Q Havn't you ever been out of the United States? A No.
Q What is your father's name? A Co Chong.
Q Has he any other name or names? A No.
Q Where is your father now? A He is dead now, died in China.
Q Was he ever in this country? A He went to China.
Q When? A K.S.26
Q How did he go? A By way of Seattle, I think. He came to Portland from San Francisco and then to Seattle.
Q What was his business in this country? A He was a laborer.
Q Where did he live? A Hop Sing Building, San Fraciscon, on Jackson Street.
